collections.title: Collections
collections.note: Every collection that is to be made accessible to the public is first checked by us.

texts.preface: The images you see during the game are from the Staatliche Kunsthalle Karlsruhe, the Rijksmuseum and the Institute for Art History at the University of Cologne, for example.
texts.principle: If you are logged in, you can also upload your own collections via the user menu. To add images, simply drag and drop the relevant files onto the interface. Two types of files are supported: images in the formats .jpg, .jpeg, .png and .gif; and metadata for the images in the formats .csv, .json or .jsonl. Images can also be submitted as .zip archives.
texts.mapping: For the metadata to be assigned correctly, the column names in the file must correspond to the following:
texts.filePath: file, path, or file_path: file path of the image
texts.title: title, titles, meta.title, or titel: title of the image
texts.creator: creator, artist, meta.creator, or künstler: artist of the image
texts.created: date, created, created_start, created_end, meta.created, entstehung, entstehung_beginn, or entstehung_ende: creation date of the image
texts.access: Your own collections are initially only visible to yourself. However, you can change the access after uploading a collection and open it for everyone. Every collection that is to be made accessible to the public is checked manually by us.

fields.summary: Since 2010, {images} images were annotated with {taggings} tags by {users} players.

texts.preface: Art history thrives on working with artworks and their digital reproductions. These are collected online in image catalogues, some of which contain several million objects. To search for images in such directories, descriptive texts are needed: a task you can help us with in a playful way—and at the same time learn a lot about art!
texts.principle: ARTigo is a collaborative platform and an example of open university research in which you participate as a player. All ARTigo games work like this: You are presented with an image. The goal is to describe this image within a certain time with keywords (tags) in such a way that as many points as possible are scored:
texts.scoreValidated: You get {n} points if the tag for this image was already given in an earlier game round
texts.scoreOpponent: You get {n} more points if you are playing with another player, and you use the same tag
texts.scoreFirst: If you are the first to describe an image, you always get {n} points per tag
texts.motivation: After you have played a predefined number of rounds, the metadata for the images become visible. In this way, you not only generate art-historical knowledge, but also collect it. Every tag you enter is saved and improves the search for artworks—a win-win situation. So, go for it!

example1.name: Mechthild
example1.value: I like the intensive engagement with the sensory perception of the artworks. The challenge of putting what you see into words is still exciting years later and anything but trivial.

example2.name: Johannes
example2.value: The variety of perceptions does not allow boredom to set in, on the contrary. It brings art into everyday life and enriches it in an uncomplicated way. An advantage that connects digital and analogue life.

example3.name: Elke
example3.value: It is nice to recognise the familiar. But it's even more exciting to discover the unknown and look it up using the metadata—and it is wonderfully simple, accessible and fun.

example4.name: Michaël
example4.value: In addition to the need for collaboration, ARTigo allows you to practice and discover lesser known artists and works. As the same themes can recur, it becomes easier to decipher movements, symbols, or characters.

texts.cooperate: Do you work for a cultural institution and would like to integrate your collections into ARTigo? Feel free to contact us with cooperation requests
texts.bugs: You can easily report bugs and feature requests via our GitHub
texts.press: Also feel free to download our press kit, licensed under a Creative Commons Licence (CC BY-SA 4.0), if you would like to write about ARTigo

fields.cis: Center for Information and Language Processing

texts.prototype: Gerhard Schön (IT-Group Humanities) develops a first prototype of a social tagging platform as a proof-of-concept.
texts.dfg: ARTigo is funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG). Under the direction of Hubertus Kohle (Institute for Art History), François Bry (Institute for Informatics), Thomas Krefeld (Institute for Romance Studies), Klaus Schulz (Center for Information and Language Processing) and Christian Riepl (IT-Group Humanities) are realising the project.
texts.spiegel: Der Spiegel presents ARTigo in the article “Lass das mal den Schwarm machen”.
texts.slb: As part of the Stadt-Land-Bild-project, ARTigo can be played in the Austrian Museum of Folk Life and Folk Art via a multimedia installation consisting of extensive touch-screen walls.
texts.relaunch: Under the directon of Stefanie Schneider (Institute for Art History), ARTigo is being re-designed and adapted to the technical state-of-the-art.
texts.provenance: To mark the 5th International Day of Provenance Research, a collection of reverse sides of artworks is offered for indexing.
texts.eu: ARTigo is awarded an „European Union Prize for Citizen Science“ (Honorary Mention).

texts.intro: We show you an image by
texts.example2: what feelings it triggers in you
